description: two old women seated at a wide table; woman in front wears dark bonnet, rests her PR fist on her cheek and has a bowl and spoon in front of her; bearded man rests his head and PR arm on table, seated between women; large covered basket in foreground, LLQ; other figures in background
inscription:
Signature, Edition, Stamp and Inscription

LRC, in pencil: [T35]
markings: see Signed; LLC below signature, lightly impressed in paper: [(illegible) SAGOT (?) / (illegible) / PARIS]
provenance: (Richard Reed Armstrong Fine Art, Chicago, until 2002; sold in April for PTOO, to Drake); Harry Drake, St. Paul (2002-d. 2012; bequeathed to MIA)
signed: LLC below image, in pencil: [Edgar Chahine 24/40]
text: Edgar Chahine often reminded his middle and upper middle class audience of the grinding burden of urban poverty. Here he focused on hunger and fatigue. The basket placed at center stage, meant for carrying food, underscores the spare offerings in this dining hall at the former Château Rouge. In the early 1800s, Château Rouge had served as headquarters for the brother of Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1861). By Chahine’s time, the building had been torn down and the land redeveloped to accommodate the influx of rural citizens and immigrants fueling Paris’s growth. The area still serves an immigrant population, with today’s newcomers coming mostly from Africa.
title: At the Château Rouge
